link_counts.title: How many devs are working on Signal?

posts.name: Jeremy
posts.cooked: Curious which piece he’ll be working on

posts.name: Harold Finch
posts.cooked: Hello, who is Alan and how us???

jeremymasters:

Curious which piece he’ll be working on

It seems he is associated with blockchain.com:

GitHub

alanevansbc - Overview

alanevansbc has one repository available. Follow their code on GitHub.

Since we got some news about MobileCoin ("Facebook and Telegram Are Hoping to Succeed Where Bitcoin Failed" (mentions Mobilecoin)), maybe he will work on the MobileCoin integration in Signal?

link_counts.title: "Facebook and Telegram Are Hoping to Succeed Where Bitcoin Failed" (mentions Mobilecoin)

posts.cooked:
minnmann:

maybe he will work on the MobileCoin integration in Signal?

Hopefully not… this would be extremely out of scope for a bloat-free messenger, IMO

Blockchain is a distributed ledger, so possibly the goal would be to improve groupchats by implementing a proper distributed-database-of-groupchat-members, rather than the current system where every client-app is an island?

From reading up about the mobileCoin stuff recently, the goal would almost certainly NOT be to bloat signalapp with wallet-functionality and crypto-token stuff… there would be a separate app, like in the days of the now-dormant Flock project, intended to replace the stock addressbook-app. Related to signalapp, in other words, but optional and not in the signalapp APK.

If I had to guess though, I suspect that Alan Evans is just a programmer who knows about crypto and infosec thanks to his past work on blockchain-stuff, much in the way Moxie is “just” a programmer who knows about infosec and crypto from his past work on SSLstrip and heavy use of encrypted email-systems and whatnot.

My advice is to be patient and watch the github repo, and see what kind of code Alan pushes :-) That will tell us more than guessing and digging ever could. And I expect we will all be quite pleased, because so far signal-foundation slash OWS has been doing exceedingly well, at carefully bringing people onboard that are already competent and already privacy-oriented

link_counts.title: Proposing clients keep eachother informed about the group
GitHub - signalapp/Flock: Private contact and calendar sync for Android.

posts.name: Jeremy
posts.cooked:
5_c_d:

My advice is to be patient and watch the github repo, and see what kind of code Alan pushes :-) That will tell us more than guessing and digging ever could. And I expect we will all be quite pleased, because so far signal-foundation slash OWS has been doing exceedingly well, at carefully bringing people onboard that are already competent and already privacy-oriented

But isn’t it fun to speculate?? I think people are just excited there is another dev and what that will bring!

Interestingly enough, of all the devs, only moxie, Michael, and now Alan are listed as members of the signal org on github,even though several more do development work.
He starred only android on GitHub. Hopefully he will begin with hardening local encryption

Then we should also welcome

GitHub

noboomu-signal - Overview

GitHub is where noboomu-signal builds software.

He started recently worrking as Senior Server Engineer…
Haha good catch yeah I noticed him too. I’m like a creep stalking the repos…

jeremymasters:

are listed as members of the signal org on github

I think this is just indicative of the individual developer pro-actively editing their github user-profile to “add themselves” but I am not familiar enough with github internals to say for sure. Greyson has commit-access, so it cannot merely be related to that, some additional step must be required.

jeremymasters:

But isn’t it fun to speculate?? I think people are just excited

We are all very serious here. No fun is to be allowed. Excitement will be punished severely. The beatings will continue until morale has improved. Now back to work, all y’all

5_c_d:

We are all very serious here. No fun is to be allowed. Excitement will be punished severely. The beatings will continue until morale has improved. Now back to work, all y’all

This is the tongue I love. Heil 5_c_d

posts.name: Greyson Parrelli
posts.cooked: Alan will be working on the Android app with me. Excited to have him on board

link_counts.title: Despite all of the scandals "WhatsApp now has 2 billion users"

posts.cooked: Nice. Let him introduce himself. You already work like 300 hours a month or even more. Thanks for your commitment. Happy to hear you get some help.

posts.name: Jeremy
posts.cooked:
greyson-signal:

Alan will be working on the Android app with me. Excited to have him on board

I’m really excited for this! Mo’ features, mo fixes!
… + hopefully better (= more convenient) UI/usability and less rough edges for existing features

posts.name: Jeremy
posts.cooked: I just know how quickly iOS version began to develop once a second person was added to the team. Being the only dev on something can be quite the task, especially given how quick the internet is to complain about every nit.
Welcome Alan! It’s really good to see the developer team grow, it can only mean great things are ahead!

posts.name: Johanw666
posts.cooked:
jeremymasters:

Being the only dev on something can be quite the task

Yes, especially when you are stuck on some blocking issue you just can’t seem to fix. And today the situation has quite improved, wich Stackoverflow as online question and answer machine. I remember the days when I started in software development and you had nothing more than the manuals and some textbooks (grandpa tells ). A colleague makes a hell of a difference.

Hah! At least you had textbooks. I remember when I was wiring up the plugboards with my teeth and mining my own ore to build enough core-memory to barely be able to store triple-digit BCD numbers …and I did it all whilst walking uphill through the snow to work…

both ways.

Textbooks would have been a luxury in those days… kids with their “software” and their “smart” phones nowadays… go into any bookstore and just BUY something about programming written on paper, rather than learning it the hard way, sheesh ;-)
